author: VitalikButerin
text: Deep funding does this for a multi-level graph: what deserves how much credit for what? If you come up with good-enough values for edges of such a graph, then you can fund a single node, and funds will automatically flow to all dependencies. Could be used as a form of issuance.

author: VitalikButerin
text: Another is distilled human judgement: AIs (or human+AI hybrids) answer a big list of questions, humans answer a randomly chosen much smaller set

author: VitalikButerin
text: One example of this is futarchy

author: VitalikButerin
text: An alternative is to create an open-access game, where humans are acting as referees in the game, and AIs are the players.

author: VitalikButerin
text: One naive way to use AI in onchain DAOs and other mechanisms is to just put a single AI in charge. But this has a lot of problems:

author: VitalikButerin

author: VitalikButerin
text: My definition of AGI: AI that's powerful enough that if one day all humans suddenly disappear and the AI is uploaded into robot bodies, it would be able to independently continue civilization. That requires a high level of capability and a very high level of generality.

author: VitalikButerin
text: ? At least I think he has some of the most detailed models of why there might be entire categories of thinking (rather than just degrees of capability) that present-day AI is missing that humans have and true general-purpose AI needs.

author: VitalikButerin
text: I'd say high bandwidth is a more dangerous assumption to make than high compute reqs. The basic reason is if you have a computer you (generally) can expect to keep that computer, but an internet connection has no such guarantees. Reasons: * censorship * disruption to internet
